The arrival of 2 of the 11 women legislators at the opening of Iran's new Parliament, the first dominated by reformers since the 1979 Islamic revolution, signaled a change. Elaheh Koulai from Tehran and Tahreh Rezazadeh from Shiraz chose not to wear the chador, the head-to-toe black covering that has been an Iranian symbol for two decades. More reformist chic than radical, they wore long shapeless coats and pinned their black scarves tightly under their chins so no hair showed, which the law requires.

The reformers' plans include increasing press freedom and creating a more prosperous economy for an overwhelmingly young population. The women's dress, though, stirred hope that the new Parliament may indeed ease religious restrictions that have dominated social life for a generation.
